Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Biennial FOBT Screening for Colorectal Cancer

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised 1:1 into screening and control arms

Participants.evidence: individuals aged 60â€“69 years, randomised 1:1 into screening and control arms

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 into screening and control arms

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the impact of biennial faecal occult blood test (FOBT) screening on colorectal cancer (CRC) outcomes beyond mortality and to investigate potential sex differences in screening effectiveness.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was CRC-specific mortality

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by birth year, sex, and residence

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 321,311 individuals were randomised, with 160,719 in the screening arm and 160,508 in the control arm.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 743 screening-detected and 617 control CRC cases.

Result_Outcome.evidence: CRC was less common in women (0.34% vs. 0.50% in men; RR 0.82, 95% CI 0.74 to 0.91).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
